item.title: Meme Sea: All Weapons and How to Get Them
item.description:
You will encounter various enemies while exploring the seas in Meme Sea , so you will need to create a strong build, and for this, the game offers you a large arsenal of weapons. In this guide, we will tell you about all the weapons in Meme Sea and how to get them.

Weapons are one of the ways to deal damage in this Roblox RPG. And even though weapons require investing points in a separate stat, it is worth it, especially if you are lucky enough to get exclusive ones.

How to Get All Meme Sea Weapons

At first glance, it may seem that the weapons in Meme Sea are less effective than Powers. But in fact, they perfectly complement the abilities of the devil fruits. Most of the weapons have long-range or AoE attacks. Therefore, with enough points invested in the Weapon stat, you can defeat any enemies.

However, unlike Powers, weapons cannot be obtained through Gacha or found under trees. Instead, you will have to explore the islands and fight enemies. Some swords can be purchased in exchange for money and certain items from NPCs, while others are dropped by strong enemies. So, below, you will find a list of all Meme Sea weapons with a description of how to obtain them.

Weapon Name Rarity How to Get
Hanger Common Can be purchased from the Hanger NPC for 7.5k Cash on Floppa Island.
Katana Common Can be purchased from the Doge NPC for 5k Cash on Floppa Island.
Flame Katana Uncommon Can be purchased from the Cheems NPC for 50k Cash and Cheems Cola on Floppa Island.
Banana Uncommon Can be purchased from the Smiling Cat NPC for 350k Cash and Cat Food on Gorilla Island.
Pixel Sword Rare Drops with a 10% chance from Obamid Boss.
Pink Hammer Rare Drops with a 10% chance from Pink Absorber Boss.
Bonk Rare Can be purchased from the Meme Man NPC for 1 million Cash and 5 Money Bags on MrBeast Island.
Card Rare Drops with a 10% chance from Reverse Master Raid Boss.
Pumpkin Legendary Can be purchased from the Gravestone NPC for 3.5 million Cash and Nugget Man on Pumpkin Island.
Yellow Blade Legendary Drops with a 5% chance from Evil Noob Boss.
Purple Katana Legendary Drops with a 5% chance from Lord Sus Boss.
Portal Legendary Drops with a 25% chance from Meme Beast Boss.
Floppa Exclusive Reward for completing Lava Floppa quest on Floppa Island.
Popcat Exclusive Can be purchased from the Ohio Popcat NPC for 10k Pops on PvP Arena. (To earn Pops players need to click the Popcat on Floppa Island)

Best Weapons in Meme Sea

With such a wide variety of weapons, every player can find something to their taste in Meme Sea . But some options should definitely be in your arsenal. This includes the Portal and Floppa. The first is the worst weapon in terms of damage since only M1 deals damage. However, it allows you to quickly teleport between islands, which makes traveling much easier.

At the same time, Floppa is the best weapon, since it has a low cooldown, good damage, and can stun enemies. In addition, it can be obtained on the starting island even before you reach level 100.

item.title: Diablo 4: Sepulcher Of The Forsworn Location
item.description:
Dungeons in Diablo 4 are great ways to earn Renown and level up your character early into a playthrough. Once you reach the endgame content, some Dungeons will earn Grim Favors and help you get rewards from the Tree Of Whispers.

Dungeons can also be turned into Nightmare Dungeons, which happens to random dungeons once you use the item. To properly farm Nightmare Dungeons, it's important to know where every dungeon is, as you have a limited time to find and complete the dungeon. One dungeon that doesn't appear on the map right away is Sepulcher Of The Forsworn; here's where to find it.

Where To Find Sepulcher Of The Forsworn In Diablo 4

The Sepulcher Of The Forsworn dungeon is found in the Altar Of Ruin region of Kehjistan . The Altar of Ruin is a Stronghold that players will first need to complete to make the entrance of the dungeon appear. The Altar Of Ruin is easily found by starting at the Iron Wolves Encampment and heading northeast to reach the stronghold which will already be marked on your map. This Stronghold does have a minimum level of 45 and will scale to your level if you attempt it at a higher level.

Clearing The Altar Of Ruin

The Altar Of Ruin is a simple stronghold that can be finished in about five minutes. The entire area is a circle, with you entering the stronghold to the left and traveling around back to where you entered but from the other side, defeating three bosses on the way. Once you've defeated the bosses and they dropped their keystones, use them on the northern door to open the way to the boss, Dark Cardinal Maldul.

After he has been defeated, the Wanderer's Shrine will be marked on your map and can be used to free the stronghold. Now the northern end of the boss room will be the entrance to the Sepulcher Of The Forsworn dungeon.

Using the Wanderer's Shrine will also unlock the waypoint to the stronghold letting you travel back to reach the dungeon easier.

What Makes Sepulcher Of The Forsworn Special

Aside from being a potential Nightmare Dungeon, Sepulcher Of The Forsworn is a useful dungeon to farm on World Tier 4 due to the boss density inside . The first section will have players face multiple mini-bosses before proceeding to the second section then the final boss, and on World Tier 4, they will often drop Ancestral gear that is well worth grinding for.

item.title: Best Mario Villains Who Arenâ€™t Bowser
item.description:
The classic Super Mario series has many touchstones, such as its iconic power-ups, music, and characters. Bowser stands out as the ever-present villain of the series. With a range of personalities varying from affable to sadistic and a memorable design, he is definitely the best of Mario's antagonists.

Even so, certain games have decided not to have him as a villain. Mario characters are often treated as players on a stage, and sometimes Bowser fits the mold of a supporting role rather than the main antagonist. Additionally, certain games billing Mario do not feature Bowser as a villain at all. Here are some of Mario's best foes outside the Koopa King.

5 Wart

Super Mario Bros. 2

  • Debuted in Doki Doki Panic
  • Appeared in Super Mario Bros 2 , a reskin of Doki Doki Panic released for western audiences
  • Leads a group called the 8 Bits, which consists of every enemy fought in Subcon

Although not originally a Mario villain, this vegetable-hating, dream-hopping frog thing fits like a glove in the palm of the still-developing Mario series. He took over Subcon, a dream land with connections to the Mushroom Kingdom. Subcon's inhabitants told Mario and friends in their dreams about Wart's weakness and urged them to stop him. After a couple of vegetables are thrown his way, he is eventually defeated.

Oddly enough, Wart also makes a less antagonistic appearance in the Legend of Zelda series, namely Link's Awakening . Here, he goes by his Japanese name, Mamu, and teaches Link the "Frog's Song of Soul" in exchange for 300 rupees. Much like Super Mario Bros 2 and Doki Doki Panic , Link's Awakening also takes place in a land of dreams, namely Koholint Island.

4 Smithy

Super Mario RPG: Legend of the Seven Stars

  • First appeared in Super Mario RPG: Legend of the Seven Stars
  • Leads the Smithy Gang, which is made up of most villains who are original to the game
  • Has not appeared in any subsequent game since

Hailing from a heavily industrialized world made of weapons, Smithy seeks to take over Mario's world as well. He stations his minion, Exor, in Bowser's keep and destroys the Star Road, the source of the world's wishes. Smithy is encountered deep in his factory, which is only accessible after being inhaled by Exor, with his mouth serving as a gateway between Smithy's world and Mario's. Smithy is shown to have multiple forms as a final boss, with each having its own strengths and weaknesses. His head can transform into anything from a tank to a cloaked sorcerer. However, Mario and friends succeed in defeating Smithy and restoring the Star Road.

Smithy's ambitions make him feel in line with the earth-destroying goals of many a Square villain, but the cartoon design he is given, along with his factory, allows such a villain to make sense in Mario's world, or more accurately adjacent to it.

3 Wario

Super Mario Land 2: 6 Golden Coins

  • Introduced as a proper antagonist to Mario in Super Mario Land 2
  • Although occasionally an antagonist since then, he is more commonly a rival or ally to Mario instead
  • Most commonly involved with Mario in spin-off games at present, otherwise sticking to his own series

Wario feels so far removed from his original appearance that more casual fans of the series may not realize he was ever a proper main antagonist at all. That said, he was designed to be an archnemesis to Mario. In Super Mario Land 2: 6 Golden Coins , Wario, a childhood acquaintance of Mario, steals the plumber's castle and puts an evil spell on it to make it his own. He confronts Mario in the game's final stage, where he initially attacks Mario by charging into him. He has two additional forms he takes after his initial defeat, Bunny Wario and Fiery Wario. Once each is defeated, he is shrunken down to size and his spell is broken.

Since this initial appearance, games with Wario as a proper villain are very few and far between. He is instead often portrayed as more of an anti-hero. Despite having his greed intact, Wario is the protagonist of series such as WarioWare and Wario Land , a sequel/spinoff of Super Mario Land . In these instances, he can, in rare instances, perform heroic or kind actions, despite his ulterior motives. Most commonly, Wario features in spinoffs such as Mario Kart and Mario Party , where he is often treated as a hero if the spinoff has a narrative. Although conceptually Wario is a fun villain, the best realization of his character traits comes when they're contrasted with his role as the protagonist.

2 Fawful

Mario & Luigi Series

  • First introduced as a supporting villain in Mario and Luigi: Superstar Saga
  • Makes a cameo in Mario and Luigi: Partners in Time
  • The main antagonist in Mario and Luigi Bowser's Inside Story

Introduced as Cackletta's right-hand man, the chortling Fawful is known for his odd speech patterns and sinister tricks. He and Cackletta often prank the brothers in Mario and Luigi: Superstar Saga , like the time they fed Queen Bean a Belly Blech to distract the brothers from his theft of the Beanstar. He is even responsible for possessing Bowser, offering his body for Cackletta to possess. Despite his efforts, the crafty Beanish and his master are both defeated by the brothers. Fawful subsequently returns in Mario and Luigi: Bowser's Inside Story , where he tricks Bowser into inhaling a vacuum shroom, setting the events of the game in motion.

He eventually steals energy from the Dark Star, becoming the powerful Dark Fawful, one of the game's final foes. He ends his efforts with a suicide bombing after becoming a stomach bug, trying to destroy the Mario Bros. along with himself. However, he is unsuccessful, instead only reversing the effects of the vacuum shroom. Fawful is somewhat fascinating as a villain, in part because of his development between his two major appearances. Although he is fine playing second fiddle to Cackletta, he is subsequently shown to pull the strings himself in the following game he is a villain. More interestingly, Cackletta's own defeat seems to have little to do with his motives in Bowser's Inside Story , as he only mentions her once in passing, specifically in the French version of the game.

1 Count Bleck

Super Paper Mario

  • First appeared in Super Paper Mario
  • Has four major minions of note: Nastasia, O' Chunks, Mimi, and Dimentio
  • Brainwashed Luigi into becoming Mr. L

Formerly known as Blumiere, Count Bleck was once a member of the Tribe of Darkness. He rejected his father's demand to not get involved with humans and fell in love with a woman by the name of Timpani. Unfortunately, once found out, Blumiere's father curses Timpani, leaving her amnesiac and banished from their dimension. It was around this time that Blumiere became Bleck and desired to destroy every world with the Dark Prognosticus.

Bleck sends his subordinates to deal with Mario and his companions from afar, but he secretly hopes they can stop his plan upon confirming Mario's helpful fairy companion, Tippi, may actually secretly be Timpani. However, once defeated, he is betrayed by Dimentio, who wishes to use the Chaos Power to become a god. However, he is ultimately thwarted by Blumiere and Timpani's mutual re-declaration of love, which summons the Pure Hearts and weakens Dimentio, leading to his defeat at the hands of Mario and his friends. Although Blumiere believed he and Timpani would die as a result of their pure-hearted sacrifice, an ending visual along with some words from Nastasia; Bleck's former assistant, and Merlon; Tippi's savior, implies the pair are living together happily in a separate world.

item.title: Zenless Zone Zero: How To Beat Nineveh
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Zenless Zone Zero Nineveh Boss Guide
  • Nineveh Boss Fight Tips

Out of the many bosses in Zenless Zone Zero , players will likely encounter Nineveh as their first colossal Ethereal. This monstrosity is one of the largest Ethereals in the ruins of old Eridu, and it's up to the players to help take it down.

Nineveh isn't particularly difficult to fight, but if you're playing Withering Garden in Zenless Zone Zero's Hollow Zero with modifiers active, then this boss is bound to give you trouble. Putting the negative modifiers aside, here's a guide covering all the important things you need to know about Nineveh.

Zenless Zone Zero Nineveh Boss Guide

You can fight Nineveh once you reach Inter-Knot Level 45, which unlocks the Withering Garden - Core node in Hollow Zero. Here, you'll be going through three floors, each representing the previous Hollow Zero stages. If you make it all the way through to the end, the boss fight will begin.

Apart from a few moves, Nineveh's attacks are obvious and very telegraphed. Scoring parries and perfect assists will whittle away the boss' health and Daze bars, eventually opening it up to your harder-hitting attacks. Once Nineveh's HP reaches certain levels, it will do the following attacks:

Ether Storm

Nineveh will go to the center of the map and cause small barriers to erupt from the ground. Then, it will unleash an Ether blast covering the entire arena, damaging everything that gets caught. To avoid this attack, simply hide behind one of the barriers.

When the attack ends, the barriers will explode, knocking your agent down. There may be cases where agents get outright incapacitated during this time â€” to avoid this, make sure to stick to the barrier as closely as you can.

Ether Onslaught

Once Nineveh's health goes down to about 30%, it will once again go to the center of the arena and summon vines around the perimeter. Then, Nineveh will start unleashing a long barrage of homing Ether projectiles that will explode on contact. This phase of the fight can get pretty hectic, as you'll have to avoid both the projectiles and the vines' attacks.

Here, we recommend ignoring the tentacles and focusing on dodging. Zenless Zone Zero characters like Nicole can use the long animations of their EX Special Attacks to avoid getting hit by the Ether projectiles. Additionally, many Perfect Dodge follow-up attacks also make your agent invincible, so try abusing those to avoid getting hit.

Nineveh Boss Fight Tips

  • Nineveh has neither Weaknesses nor Resistances. Use anyone you like.
  • Your stunner or main Anomaly character should be the one doing most of the fighting.
  • Stunners like Anby deal more Daze after performing a Perfect Dodge. If your character has a similar effect, abuse Nineveh's telegraphed attacks.
  • You can trigger Perfect Dodges by dashing into Nineveh whenever it does its spin attack.
  • Hornets will spawn during the fight. Use them to trigger Resonia effects that require defeating enemies.

item.title: 5 RPGs That Have You Grow Stronger By Building Relationships With NPCs
item.description:
The RPG genre is one of the most popular in the history of gaming. Ever since the first RPG video game came out several decades ago, players have become addicted to games that follow this template, spending hundreds of hours completing every quest, talking to every character, and leveling their skills to slay their enemies. That said, as wonderful as RPGs are, they're not all created equal, as some have more game mechanics than others, which makes them considerably more interesting.

Some RPGs treat NPC companions as nothing but random characters that players can occasionally talk to and use as battle allies or even cannon fodder. However, others truly take advantage of their potential importance and turn them into clever ways for the character to become more powerful, gain new skills, and even unlock several side quests for additional hours of fun.

5 Dragon Age: Inquisition

Companions' Approval Carries Great Weight

  • Gathering allies and gaining their approval grants valuable abilities
  • Questlines expand every interaction

Dragon Age: Inquisition is a welcome continuation to the saga, adding new weapons, abilities, storylines, and a wide range of characters that complement the game beautifully. While exploring the world of Thedas, players will come across many dangers and creatures to interact withâ€”some friendly, some not.

By talking to as many NPCs as possible and earning their favor, players can improve their companions' approval rating to unlock new quests, combat strategies, and abilities, which can come in handy when enemies are charging against them.

4 Star Wars: Knights Of The Old Republic

Inspire Companions For Improved Skills And Side Quests

  • Items and Light/Dark points can be obtained by interacting with NPCs and intervening in conflicts
  • By talking to NPCs, new quests are unlocked and there are romance possibilities

Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is, arguably, one of the best RPGs of the early 2000s, and possibly one of the best ever made. With its classic RPG turn-based combat style, great character, and world design, and nearly endless possibilities in terms of armor, weapons, and Force powers, this game was years ahead of its time. As the main character's story is unraveled, they will meet many NPCs on the arduous journey to find the Star Map and defeat the evil Darth Malak.

Talking to world NPCs will not only unlock additional dialogue options, side quests, and certain items but can also allow the main character to romance Bastila as she witnesses the main character's noble actions. While the game itself is pretty long and there are plenty of side quests to cover without talking to NPCs, conversations with them add another layer of depth to game interactions and can help boost the leveling process.

3 Fallout 4

Happy Companions Grant Useful Perks

  • Increasing Companion Affinity unlocks new perks
  • Companion approval or disapproval can impact gameplay

Exploring a post-apocalyptic nuclear wasteland 200 years after the bombs dropped is a golden scenario for a survival RPG, and no one understood that better than Bethesda Studios. Surviving the Boston Commonwealth can be very challenging, as it's plagued with giant insects, cannibal super mutants, deranged robots, and vicious Deathclawsâ€”having a strong bond with the right companions is not a nice-to-have, but rather a critical aspect of the game.

Anyone who's played a Fallout game knows that with every one of the character's main actions, there will be a reaction from their companions. Positive reactions can result in improved perks, better combat abilities, and new possibilities for additional storylines, whereas negative reactions will have the opposite effect. Since Fallout is largely a perk-based game with a strong resource management focus, getting along with NPC companions to make traversing the wasteland easier is strongly advised.

2 The Witcher 3

Conversations With Friends Unlock Hours Of Fun

  • Talking to NPCs and developing a relationship with them unlocks side quests with precious rewards
  • Various romance options can be unlocked through interaction

When The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt came out, it redefined what "Next Gen" meant at the time. Not only because of the great graphics it had but also because of the amazing, lively, vast world players got to explore. By continuing Geralt's story, players were able to reconnect with old companions from previous games, while also meeting new, interesting ones that added complexity, richness, and depth to the main story.

In The Witcher 3 , companion relationships help make Geralt stronger not through unlocking new powers and perks, but rather through unlocking new side quests that culminate with the Gray Wolf getting legendary armor, swords, and other rare items. Great examples of this are the armors from all Witcher schools, the fabled Aerondight, and small fortunes here and there, which can be used to upgrade items and buy potion ingredients.

1 The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim

Gaining Favors Across Tamriel

  • Gaining merchants' favor can result in discounts and gifts
  • Saving some NPCs unlocks side quests

The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim, is, undeniably, a masterpiece that has withstood the test of time, as it's been almost a decade and a half since its release and there are still hundreds of thousands of players worldwide exploring the lands of Tamriel. While traversing the world, players will come across many dangers and situations where they can help others. By saving NPCs and interfering in conflicts, players can get considerable discounts in shops, and also unlock different side quests that often yield valuable rewards and even invitations to join a specific guild.

Collecting valuable items and being able to purchase better armor, weapons, and other combat elements for cheap can be a great advantage before battling the powerful bosses that roam Tamriel.
